title: Hospitals to be hammered by business rate rises while web giants like Amazon to see costs fall
text:
Hospitals to be hammered by business rate rises while web giants like Amazon to see costs fall The first overhaul of levies in seven years is expected to clobber NHS trusts and family doctors with a multimillion pound hike Share Comments By Ben Glaze 17:04, 15 FEB 2017 News Hospitals and GP surgeries to be hit by business rate hike (Photo: Getty) politics Hospitals and GP surgeries are set to be hammered by business rate rises while web giants like Amazon see costs plunge, it has emerged.
The first overhaul of levies in seven years is expected to clobber NHS trusts and family doctors with a multimillion pound hike.
But vast companies with sprawling out-of-town warehouses and no high street shops are likely to see taxes tumble.
Rates are due to fall at six of Amazon’s nine UK distribution centres, with the online retailer expected to scoop a £140,000 windfall.
The company triggered fury when it emerged in 2015 that it had paid £11.9million in tax while its Luxembourg unit took £5.3billion of sales from British internet shoppers without being subject to UK levies.
Meanwhile, hospital bosses fear big rises will pile pressure on their stretched budgets.
Read More Debenhams, 118 and Peacocks among firms named and shamed by Business Minister Margot James for failing to pay minimum wage Amazon will see its costs fall (Photo: Getty) Jerry Schurder, of analysts Gerald Eve, which advises companies and public sector bodies on business rates, said: “At a time when the NHS is under huge budgetary pressures, these rises in business rates liabilities highlight just how punitive the system has become and will be a cause of real concern for those tasked with delivering hospital and clinic services.”
Revaluations of how much premise and sites are worth are linked to property prices, meaning the shake-up will create winners and losers.
Some pubs and independent shops warn they could crash out of business because of eyewatering rises of up to 300%.
Hospitals will be hit hard because they occupy such big sites and the equivalent cost of rebuilding - on which the rate is based - would be high.
The analysis found that business rates for hospitals will rise from £328million to £418million in five years.
GPs and health centres will see their costs rise from £257million to £332million annually over the same period.
Some health authorities will have to pay millions more, according to an analysis reported by the Telegraph.
Peterborough City Hospital will see rates rocket from £2.5million to £4.8million by 2021.
Peterborough City Hospital will see its business rates rise (Photo: Alamy) The University Hospital Birmingham NHS Trust’s bill is set to climb from £4.2million to £7.6million.
Royal London Hospital in east London will face an increase of nearly 60% to £9.7million.
Meanwhile, business leaders stepped up demands for Chancellor Philip Hammond to tackle anomalies in the tax system which will see high street shops pay higher rates on small premises than online giants do for vast warehouses.
The Institute of Directors demanded he use next month’s(MAR) Budget to set up a New Economy Tax Commission to make the system fit for the modern age of internet shopping and the “platform economy”.
Amazon is expected to see its overall bill nine UK warehouses to plunge by more than £140,000,
In Swansea, the rateable value of its warehouse has been cut from £2.2 million to £1.9million.
Its Doncaster warehouse has seen a £100,000 reduction in its estimated value.
But the company insisted rates for its London head office would rise.
All businesses with properties with a rateable value above £12,000 have to pay business rates.
The levies will fall for 920,000 businesses, stay the same for 420,000, and increase for 510,000.
